results.title: Feed them to the cannibals!
results.creator_credit: Fiona Cunningham Reid, Baobab Productions and Dangerous to Know
results.brief_description: In 1972 a small number of lesbians and gay men held the first Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras in Sydney, a then militant solidarity march for gay rights. Over the last two decades the Sydney Gay Mardi Gras has become one of the biggest festivals around the world, attracting hundreds of thousands of international and domestic tourists every year. The film explores the history of the Sydney lesbian and gay community, a community organised around relationships of love, solidarity and pleasure and which is challenging the traditional ways society has understood family, love and commitment. Many of the activists interviewed discuss the changes in gay and lesbian politics over the last twenty years and the changes in the lived experiences of non-heterosexuality.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fiona Cunningham Reid, Baobab Productions and Dangerous to Know

results.title: Faust
results.creator_credit: Friedrich W. Murnau, Erich Pommer and UFA
results.brief_description: Classic silent German cinema from the talented F.W.Murnau, 1926. “The portals of darkness are open and the shadows of the dead hunt over the earth..” opens the film with the prevailing theme of good versus evil as the devil Mephisto does a deal with alchemist Faust for his soul and potentially for dominion over the Earth - promising he will stop the plague that is rife throughout Faust’s village. Faust reneges on the arrangement choosing love - much to the delight of Archangel St. Michael. Based on the original story by Goethe. Great cinematography and effects give the film a dark foreboding and general creepiness that add to the dramatic impact of the work. This edition features orchestral soundtrack by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Friedrich W. Murnau, Erich Pommer and UFA

results.title: Father, son and holy war. Parts 1 and 2
results.brief_description: Controversial Indian filmmaker Anand Patwardhan (War and peace = Jang aur aman) is confronting and courageous in tackling head on in this two-part documentary, the religious and political violence which currently exists in India today between the Hindi majority and the Islamic minority. More importantly however, is the understanding and historical background of India’s culture and belief system which is provided through personal stories and interviews from a broad spectrum of societal, political and religious Hindus and Muslims. Anand examines the crisis of male identity among the Hindus and their obsession with male strength, power and control over their women and over Muslims. He also highlights the rise of civil rights and women’s resistance movements and the call for equality and peace between the two religions. Anand walks the fine line in his attempt to maintain balance but the overriding issue is that of women, whether Hindu or Muslim, and their appalling treatment by extremists from both sides. Part 1. Trial by fire: Begins with a Hindu perspective of the Bombay riots in 1993 where Hindus set fire to Muslim shops and then follows with a historical look into how and why matriarchal India turned into the patriarchal India of today with its roots of continuing religious violence. Part 2. Hero pharmacy: Explores manhood, sexuality and physicality and their relationship to conflict and violence, juxtaposed with the awareness by women of their own place in society and a calling for unity, equality and humanity in religion. Also shows the 1993 Bombay riots from a Muslim perspective. Includes some b&w footage. In English and Hindi with English subtitles.

results.title: Reaction: portrait of a society in crisis
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, Normand Cloutier, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: People from various English-speaking groups in Montreal and other places in Quebec express their personal reactions to the October Crisis of 1970 when Quebec nationalism took a violent turn. A British diplomat had been kidnapped, a Quebec cabinet minister murdered. The troops were brought in as a safeguard. This film is a vigorous reflection of the discussions and analyses of the situation that went on wherever people gathered, voicing attitudes and fears, sympathies and concerns.

results.title: Reaching out: a story about mainstreaming
results.creator_credit: John Cosgrove, Terry Dunn, Educational Media and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Looks at the difficulties and rewards of integrating the handicapped into regular classrooms. Shows Mary, a severely deaf child with limited speech capabilities and cerebral palsy, and how she copes with mainstreaming.

results.title: Real inside
results.creator_credit: David Verrall, John Weldon, Derek Lamb, Douglas MacDonald and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Meet Buck Boom—dynamic, forceful and creative—and a candidate for the job of executive assistant at a staid corporation. There’s no doubt in Boom’s mind that he’s the person for the job, but the question is, can he convince Mr. Mudgin, the personnel manager? For, you see, Boom is a cartoon and Mudgin is not used to dealing with someone who is “different.” Skillfully crafted, using an innovative combination of live action and animation techniques, this hilarious short film probes stereotypes, prejudices and hiring practices.

results.title: Ready or not
results.creator_credit: Colin Budds, David Campbell, Michael Vaughan and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: Conflict arises when a small factory facing closure is taken over by a large corporation who use it as a test case for the introduction of modern computerised manufacturing equipment. Relations between workers, management and unions deteriorate rapidly until an accident in the factory brings differences to a head.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Budds, David Campbell, Michael Vaughan and Film Victoria

results.title: Ready for the hills
results.creator_credit: Maurice Dybeck, Peter Halket and Explorer Films
results.brief_description: A training film on the basic essentials of hillcraft including training beforehand, blisters and the need for boots, type of anorak; windproof or waterproof, keeping together, the correct pace; how to walk, ascent and descent; the need for a leader, contrasts in weather conditions, food for lunch; emergency rations, drinking water and other refreshments, litter, first aid kit, map and compass, staying at youth hostels.

results.title: Reach for the sky (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Lewis Gilbert, Daniel M. Angel and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: The acclaimed film biography of British World War II hero, Douglas Bader, who after losing both legs in an aeroplane crash, overcame insurmountable odds to become one of the most decorated and remarkable fighter aces in history. The film is based on the best-selling biography, “Douglas Bader”, written by Paul Brickhill. The film stars Kenneth More.
